aws::graph::propositions: # Postaccident Examination of Aircraft After Engine Failure
The postaccident examination was conducted by a certified airframe and powerplant mechanic.
The postaccident examination was supervised by the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) investigator-in-charge (IIC).
A Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) inspector attended the postaccident examination.
A differential cylinder pressure tester was used to check the right engine's pressure.
The right engine's pressure check revealed no anomalies.
The right engine's condition was determined to be sufficient to allow for safe starter engagement.
The right engine starter was engaged during examination.
The right engine gearing rotated when the starter was engaged.
The right engine propeller rotated when the starter was engaged.
No anomalies were noted during the right engine starter engagement test.
The fuel system continuity was established during examination.
The function of the fuel selectors was established during examination.
The right fuel selector detents were checked at each selected position.
The fuel selectors were disassembled during examination.
The examination and disassembly of the fuel selectors revealed no anomalies.
The NTSB IIC verified the fuel quantity in the auxiliary (tip) tanks.
The auxiliary (tip) tanks were about full.
The fuel quantity was observed to be about two inches from the top of the auxiliary tanks.
Flight control continuity was established throughout all primary flight control surfaces.
Flight control continuity was established from the cockpit controls.
The examination of the airframe revealed no evidence of mechanical anomalies.
The examination of the airframe revealed no evidence of failures that would have precluded normal operations.
The examination of the engine revealed no evidence of mechanical anomalies.
The examination of the engine revealed no evidence of failures that would have precluded normal operations.
Additional information is available in the Airframe and Engine Examination Report in the Public docket.
The pilot reported to the NTSB IIC that the accident airplane had 30 gallons of fuel onboard during takeoff.
The pilot had flown the airplane about 3.7 hours since the last refueling.
The pilot flew the last flight using the main fuel tanks.
The NTSB IIC reviewed the performance figures in the Airplane's Flight Manual (AFM).
The reported 30 gallons of fuel remaining for the accident flight seemed to be accurate.
The airplane's total fuel capacity is 120 gallons with the tip (auxiliary) tanks.
The tip tanks fuel capacity is 30 gallons.
There is 3 gallons of unusable fuel in each main tank.
The AFM procedure for takeoff calls for the fuel selector valves to be selected "on" to the main tanks.

text:
# Postaccident Examination

Postaccident examination of the airplane and engine was conducted by a certified airframe and powerplant mechanic, under the supervision of the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) investigator-in-charge (IIC), and with an FAA inspector in attendance.

## Right Engine Examination

The right engine was examined. A differential cylinder pressure tester was used to check the appropriate pressure and resulted in no anomalies. The engine's condition was determined to be sufficient, to allow for the safe engagement of the starter. The starter was engaged and the engine gearing and propeller rotated, with no anomalies noted.

## Fuel System Continuity

The fuel system continuity and the function of the fuel selectors were established. The right fuel selector detents were checked at each selected position. The examination and disassembly of the fuel selectors revealed no anomalies. The NTSB IIC verified the fuel quantity in the auxiliary (tip) tanks were about full. The fuel quantity was observed to be about two inches from the top of the tanks.

## Flight Control Continuity

Flight control continuity was established throughout all primary flight control surfaces from the cockpit controls.

## Airframe and Engine Examination

The examination of the airframe and engine revealed no evidence of mechanical anomalies or failures that would have precluded normal operations. For additional information, see the Airframe and Engine Examination Report in the Public docket.

## Fuel Onboard and Capacity

The pilot reported to the NTSB IIC that the accident airplane had 30 gallons of fuel onboard during takeoff. He had flown the airplane about 3.7 hours since the last refueling and flew the last flight using the main fuel tanks. Reviewing the performance figures in the Airplane's Flight Manual (AFM), for the average engine fuel flow at the higher density altitudes, the reported 30 gallons of fuel remaining, for the accident flight seemed to be accurate. The airplane's total fuel capacity is 120 gallons with the tip (auxiliary) tanks. The tip tanks fuel capacity is 30 gallons. Additionally, there is 3 gallons of unusable fuel in each main tank.

## Fuel Selector Procedures

The AFM procedure for takeoff calls for the fuel selector valves to be selected "on" to the main tanks.
